title: 107_s1271
content: The Small Business Paperwork Relief Act of 2001 may be cited as the Act. It aims to facilitate compliance with federal paperwork requirements. The Small Business Paperwork Relief Act of 2001 amends the Paperwork Reduction Act to require the Director of OMB to publish a list of compliance assistance resources for small businesses annually. Additionally, it establishes an agency point of contact for this purpose. Title 44, United States Code, is amended to require each agency with a head listed at a level I position on the Executive Schedule to establish a point of contact for small business concerns regarding information collection and paperwork control. This point of contact must be established within one year of the enactment of the Small Business Paperwork Relief Act of 2001 and will act as a liaison between the agency and small businesses. The agencies included are the Federal Communications Commission, the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the Environmental Protection Agency. The Small Business Paperwork Relief Act of 2001 requires agencies with top-level officials to designate a point of contact for small businesses to address paperwork concerns. The act aims to reduce information collection burdens for small businesses, particularly those with fewer than 25 employees, and eliminate unnecessary paperwork requirements. Establishment of Task Force on Information Collection and Dissemination. Establishment of a task force to study streamlining requirements for small businesses regarding information collection and dissemination. Members appointed by department heads to include representatives from the Department of Labor. The task force established to study streamlining requirements for small businesses includes representatives from various government agencies such as OSHA, EPA, DOT, SBA, IRS, HHS, USDA, DOI, and GSA. The task force includes representatives from various government agencies and the small business community. They are tasked with recommending a plan for an interactive Government application to help small businesses understand Federal requirements and regulatory obligations. The task force is examining ways to integrate information collection across Federal agencies for small businesses, including consolidating requirements and publishing a list of collections. The task force is examining ways to integrate information collection for small businesses by publishing a list of collections organized by NAICS code, industrial/sector description, or other means to help small businesses comply with requirements. They will also assess cost savings from electronic paperwork submissions and explore ways to improve information dissemination. The task force will submit a report of its findings to specified committees and the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman within a year of the enactment of the Small Business Paperwork Relief Act of 2001. The term 'small business concern' is defined under section 3 of the Small Business Act. A technical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 35 of title 44, United States Code. Establishment of task force on information collection and dissemination and authorization of appropriations. Regulatory enforcement reforms. Section 223 of the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act of 1996 is amended to require agencies to submit reports on enforcement actions to specific government committees every 1 or 2 years. The Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act of 1996 is amended to require agencies to submit reports on enforcement actions, including the number of civil penalties assessed, reductions or waivers of penalties, and definitions of key terms. The Senate passed S. 1271 on December 17, 2001, amending title 44 of the United States Code to help small businesses comply with federal paperwork requirements and establish a task force for information collection and dissemination.
